node.title: SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator produces speckled pattern instead of the full surface
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I'm a relatively new user of moose and for my first non-tutorial simulation I am stuck at defining sidesets in order to define boundary conditions. I have a mesh generated with gmsh that consists of a single surface. I wanted to use the SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator to simply have a separate sideset for the x and y side. If I only output the mesh the result is the speckled pattern seen below:

My code looks like this:
[Problem]
    solve = false
[]

[Mesh]
    [roi]
        type = FileMeshGenerator
        file = 'mesh.msh'
        dim = 3
    []

    [sideSet]
        type = SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator
        input = roi
        new_boundary = 'x-side
                        y-side'
        replace = true
        normals = 
            '1 0 0
             0 1 0'
        tolerance = 1e5
        variance = 1e-1
        fixed_normal = false
    []
[]

[Outputs]
    exodus = true
[]

The goal would be to have the whole side covered. I tried playing around with the tolerance and variance parameters but without improving the result. The files I used are
sideset-problem.zip
I also tried to use the SideSetsFromPointsGenerator but that did not produce any sideset at all.
Perhaps Moose is not the right tool for the job. However, e.g. Paraview does not offer a straight-forward way to define new sidesets or something similar. If you have an idea of any different approach or a different tool I could use, or if you think this is the wrong way to go proceed I would be happy to hear other suggestions.
Thanks a lot!
Boundaries such as this are typically added with the program that created the mesh. I am not familiar with gmsh, but perhaps @lindsayad could help out.

Thanks for your comment.
Yes, I figured that there must be some other possibilities. I'm currently working with a single .stl file that encodes the full surface. In gmsh there is the possibility to assign different physical groups to geometric entities but at least in the GUI I could not find the option to split my one surface into multiple geometric entities in order to assign different names to different sections.
The tolerance you are using on the sideset generator is too big. I think you meant to use 1e-5 not 1e5
Changing the tolerance parameter was one of the first things I tried. At least visually, the values 1e5, 1, 1e-5 and 1e-10 all produce the same result.

Closing this.
I ll add a note to the sidesetfromnormalgenerator. It also does internal faces.
The right one to use here was
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator.html
with a normals argument

node.title: Peacock crashing
node.bodyText:
Hi All,
I tried to run the peacock by run "./peacock", But it always shows an error like this "zsh: segmentation fault  ./peacock" and python quit unexpectedly like the following:
process:               python3.7 [24078]
Path:                  /Users/USER/*/python
Identifier:            python3.7
Version:               0
Code Type:             X86-64 (Native)
Parent Process:        zsh [23344]
Responsible:           Terminal [432]
User ID:               501
How to solve this problem?

Hi,
You seem to be using the system python. Did you install moose using conda? If so you need to use the conda python.
Guillaume

Hi,
I think I installed moose using conda. I followed the installation instructions from the moose website: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
Ethan

what does which python return?
We need peacock to use the python from conda
It returns to "/Users/chongjie/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/python"

Ok it might be a different issue then
@aeslaughter will know more about Peacock failures on mac
Are you using BigSur? It was only recently that we have peacock working with it. @milljm did you get BigSur working?
Yes, I use BigSur.

Unfortunately, Big Sur won't work, until this PR makes it in: #17106, #17105
A work-around, would be for you to build these Conda packages yourself. If you're willing, I can walk you through it. It will require sudo rights.

Hi @milljm ,
Can you explain the necessary steps for this issue? I am having the same issue with Peacock on Bigsur.
Thank you.

I had a similar question earlier. I'll paste here what I wrote them:
cd moose
# add my remote (for the updated recipes necessary for BigSur).
git remote add jason https://github.com/milljm/moose
git fetch jason
git checkout jason/17105-python3.9
# get out of the moose environment if it's activated
conda deactivate
cond install conda-build
cd conda/mpich
conda build .
cd ../libmesh_vtk
conda build . --use-local
cd ../petsc
conda build . --use-local
cd ../libmesh
conda build . --use-local
cd ../tools
conda build .
If all goes well, you'll have all the moose-packages built locally. To install these into a new environment:
conda create -n bigsur --use-local moose-tools
conda activate bigsur
conda install --use-local moose-libmesh
Hopefully that works! Once installed, you can safely move back to using moose/master head.

Thank you.
I am getting error after following step

cd conda/mpich


conda build .

Last few lines before this error

checking build system type... x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0

node.title: Tutorial 2: MultiApps has an invalid link
node.bodyText:
The page (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/index.html) has an invalid link: https://mooseframework.org/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/slides
The page (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Transfers/index.html) has an invalid link to the MultiApps: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/MultiApps/index.md. I think the correct link is: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/MultiApps/index.html

Thank you for reporting this!
There's a PR up for the website to fix the first point momentarily.
In the mean time, you can build this documentation locally with
cd tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/doc
python moosedocs.py build --serve

I ll make a PR to address the second point.

node.title: Linear solutions to a nonlinear equation
node.bodyText: I am applying the following two kernels, TimeDerivative and BodyForce to solve the equation d/dt(u)=-Cu. The problem is an initial condition problem. The numerical solution from MOOSE results in a linear decrease in u over the time period. The analytical solution results in a exponential decrease in u over time. Is there a better combination of kernels that should be applied in order to get the expected exponential decrease in u?

Hello
I think you mean to use CoupledForce. BodyForce is just C not Cu
Guillaume

Thank you for the assistance. I changed the kernel to a CoupledForce, the result was the same linear trend. I then added Diffusion of the coupled v value of the CoupledForce. The results was also the same as the previous two methods used.

How many time steps are you taking?
Did you specify ‘v=u’ for the couples force kernel?
Current 130 time steps. Have used up to 13000 time steps with the same result. I did not set v = u.
Tried to define v = u. Got the following message: Coupled variable 'v' needs to be different from 'variable' with CoupledForce, consider using Reaction or somethig similar.
You should use the CoefReaction kernel for the reaction term. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/kernels/CoefReaction.html
That was the final missing piece, CoefReaction. Thank you both for helping me with this. The trend of the numerical solution is now in proper agreement with the analytical solution.

Implementation of this provided the solutions to the nonlinear trend of the numerical solution:
hugary1995:   You should use the CoefReaction kernel for the reaction term. https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/kernels/CoefReaction.html.
I ll review the documentation to make sure everything is clear. There should not be a confusion between BodyForce/CoupledForce and Reaction.

node.title: Question on the KKS AC kernels
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
There might be something really simple that I misunderstood, but why both the KKSACBulkC and KKSACBulkF kernels do not have the mobility L multiplied to their residual and on-diagonal Jacobian? Only the off-diagonal Jacobian is multiplied by L. Another kernel for the order parameter, ACInterface however, has the L in its residual and Jacobian functions. Thanks.
@jiangwen84 if you could please help with this question
The non split KKS formulation is not recommended for use. Please use the split formulation. The non split has faulty Jacobians.
Source: I wrote all those classes

@dschwen Yes I am indeed using the split formulation by KKSACBulkC, KKSACBulkF, ACInterface, KKSSplitCHCRes, and SplitCHWRes. I am wondering why in the KKSACBulkC and KKSACBulkF, the residual and on-diagonal Jacobian terms are not multiplied by the Allen-Cahn mobility L, and only the off-diagonal Jacobian is multiplied by L?

Just follow the call chain. computeDFDOP is what gets overridden by the KKSACBulkC and KKSACBulkF kernels. The offdiagonal Jacobian is handled a bit differently, as it does not use anything from the ACBulk base class, and all contributions (including the L) are implemented there directly.

@dschwen Got it. With the local solve approach though, currently the KKS kernels directly inherit from the Kernel class. They just use the computeQpResidual and computeQpJacobian instead of computeDFDOP. In that case, the mobility L needs to be multiplied in the residual and Jacobian. The hierarchy could be changed in the future if needed. Thanks for clearing that up.

node.title: How to use the value calculated from postprocessors in the "DerivativeParsedMaterial" type "Material"
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE group,
I use the order parameter and "ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor" to calculate the bubble size in the Postprocessors.
[./bubble_area]
type = ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor
variable = eta
execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
[../]
Then I try to use this calculated value in the "DerivativeParsedMaterial" type "Material".
[R_bubble]
type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
f_name = R_bubble
function = 'sqrt(bubble_area/3.1415926)'
postprocessor_names = 'bubble_area'
derivative_order = 1
outputs = 'exodus'
[]
But this is some error:
Invalid function
sqrt(bubble_area/3.1415926)
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier
Does anyone know why this happens? It seems like "DerivativeParsedMaterial" cannot get the 'bubble_area' from the postprocessor.
Many thanks,
Peng

Hi Peng
Maybe it s an issue with the derivative order parameter? What derivative are you planning on having?
The syntax looks fine to me otherwise
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thanks for your reply. I use ParsedMaterial and try it again. But still have the same error. Maybe the "postprocessor_names = 'bubble_area'" in the "Material" do not work.
I found a similar discussion. "Use a GenericFunctionMaterial to capture the PostProcessor value and add it to ParsedMaterial using the material_property_names parameter".
#15784
It can work using that approach!
Peng
That's not a satisfactory solution! test/tests/materials/derivative_material_interface/postprocessors.i shows that the postprocessor_names parameter is working. I'm checking out your example now.

The input snippet above works for me. Please make sure you are not getting any warnings from your MOOSE app and double check the spelling in your input. You might want to attach a complete input file if possible.

I run the example test/tests/materials/derivative_material_interface/postprocessors.i. But I got the error:
Lmod is automatically replacing "python/3.8" with "vtk/8.2.0".
�[31m
*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
time^2
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier�[39m
srun: Job step aborted: Waiting up to 32 seconds for job step to finish.
�[31m
*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
time^2
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier�[39m

MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 0 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.
NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.

MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 1 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.
NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.
slurmstepd: error: *** STEP 5345226.0 ON c0700a-s18 CANCELLED AT 2021-07-22T11:10:42 ***
srun: error: c0700a-s18: tasks 0-1: Exited with exit code 1
Is this the problem with my MOOSE app?
Ok, step one is to run all the tests in MOOSE. All tests should pass. If they don't, you have a different problem entirely.
What system are you on?

I update the MOOSE and run it again. It can work now! I think it's because of the version.
Many thanks.
Peng

node.title: Initial conditions for multiple blocks
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose users,
I am looking into multiphase simulations in which each phase is defined by a block. I would like to assign initial values of a variable to each block, say c=0.6 for block 1 and c=0.4 for block 2. It would look something like:
[./eta1]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    [./InitialCondition]
    variable = c
    type = ?
    value = '0.6   0.4'
    block = '1   2'
    [../]
  [../]

What could be the type in this code? I tried ConstantIC, ArrayConstantIC, ScalarComponentIC but could not get the syntax right. I would like to avoid Boundingbox as the blocks may not always be box-shaped as attached.
Warm regards,
Ritam Chatterjee
IIT Bombay, India
You can follow this example: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/test/tests/ics/constant_ic/subdomain_constant_ic_test.i

Thank you Gary. This works perfect!
Best regards,
Ritam

node.title: Material Derivative with Respect to x
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I'm currently trying to create a custom kernel and I need to calculate the derivative of a material with respect to x. I have been using SplitCHCParsed.C as an example to do this.
This is the code I have right now for getting the derivative:
CoefDiffusionMod::CoefDiffusionMod(const InputParameters & parameters) :  DerivativeMaterialInterface<JvarMapKernelInterface<SplitCHCRes>>(parameters), _dFdc(getMaterialPropertyDerivative<Real>("m_name", _var.name())) { }
Real CoefDiffusionMod::computeDFDC(PFFunctionType type) { return _dFdc[_qp]; }
I hope someone can shed some light on how to use x in place of _var.name() if it is possible.
Thanks,
Nathan

Hello
So you're looking for the first component of the gradient. You can't take gradients of material properties in moose right now, but you can use a MaterialRealAux kernel to turn the material property into an aux variable, then get the gradient of that.
The only issue is that aux variables do not leverage automatic differentiation, so the Jacobian will no longer be exact just using AD. If this becomes a problem, you can remedy this by re-writing the computeJacobian routine to add the contribution of the gradient of the material property manually.
Please do not paste screenshots in your future posts, they are not searchable
Guillaume
if you are on a longer time scale (at least a few months), we are in the midst of developing a new functor-based on-demand material system that will be able to do this.

Finally 3rd option, inspired by @hugary1995 's idea, you can define a material that is simply grad_F (or dF_dx if you only need the x-derivative) and do the chain rule yourself, using the gradient of each variable this material depends on.
Urgh, I guess then we are ignoring all chain rules associated with inhomogeneous material properties...
@hugary1995 DerivativeParsedMaterial has support for chain rule derivatives for inhomogeneous material properties!

So in short, it is possible, but it will require a bit more work (as the inhomogeneous material properties require two layers of chain rule derivatives).
We're doing the gradient calculation this way routinely in the phase field module!

node.title: Running Chigger to extract images from output files
node.bodyText:
Hi
I wrote a python script to extract the images from MOOSE output files. The code works well on my personal computer (Linux), but I get a Segmentation fault when I run it on a cluster computer. I use Chigger as below:
reader = chigger.exodus.ExodusReader(filepath)
reader.setOptions(block=['0'])
result = chigger.exodus.ExodusResult(reader)
result.setOptions(edge_color=[0, 0, 0], variable='c1', block=['0'], cmap='grayscale', local_range=True, camera=camera)
window = chigger.RenderWindow(result, offscreen=True)
print("after chigger.RenderWindow")
imagename =”%s_100hr.jpg"%folder[4:]
#window.start()
print("before window.write, imagename is ",imagename)
window.write(imagename)
print("after chigger.RenderWindow")
The segmentation error comes up with "window.write(imagename)". Could you please help me to solve this problem?
Thanks
Amir

chigger needs an active display for rendering. In theory there should be a way to compile VTK to operate using software rendering. We have tried several times over the years to get that working, but have failed in each attempt.

Thank you for your reply. If I understood you correctly, I need to have GUI to run Chigger. So, using offscreen=true in window = chigger.RenderWindow(result, offscreen=True) is not enough, and we will get a segmentation error.

Correct. The "offscreen=True" just doesn't show the window, but still requires openGL and a screen. I need to improve the error message for this case. Better yet figure out how to make it work, but that will be awhile, if ever.
Got it! Thank you very much!

@aeslaughter
Hi Andrew,
I am running the python code based on chigger to extract microstructures from MOOSE output files. I have more than 2000 output folders with 61 output files inside them. In fact, I want to extract more than 120,000 images. The code is doing well on the small number of output directories (less than 50). But when I want to run it for all 2000 directories, I get the following error message:
with open(filename, "a+") as f: # "a+" to make sure it gets created
OSError: [Errno 5] Input/output error: '/run/user/1001/gvfs/smb-share:server=cifs-prd-01,share=research/MahmoodMamivand/common/CMDLab/Fe_Cr_Co/time_temp_comp/MOOSE_results/run_cr0.05_co0.35_T870/FeCrCo_cr0.05_co0.35_T870_exodus.e-s043'

Exodus Library Warning/Error: [vtkexodusII_ex__check_valid_file_id]
ERROR: In "vtkexodusII_ex_close", the file id 65536 was not obtained via a call to "ex_open" or "ex_create".
	It does not refer to a valid open exodus file.
	Aborting to avoid file corruption or data loss or other potential problems.

65536 is the maximum 16-bit integer + 1, so I'm hitting a limit somewhere. Does the chigger interface have a method to clean up its internals? What is your suggestion? Thank you very much for your consideration,
Sincerely,
Amir
output.txt
This is some sort of system limitation and an unsure of the proper fix, I am wondering if it is as easy as changing the ulimit. @milljm has more experience in this realm, perhaps he can chime in.
Thanks for your response. I tried  ulimit before. It doesn't work for me.

You might want to try offloading the data onto a hard disk location (if I am reading that mount point correctly /media). Is that a thumb stick?
Or, try moving the data to a Unix filesystem such as EXT (if it's in fact a SMB mount to a Windows share). The last I heard (which was a long time ago, and I am probably wrong), is reading/writing to NTFS filesystems and the like was experimental.

Thank you Jason, I read the output files from Windows share storage (SMB). It's interesting because it works well when I run it on a small number of output directories (less than 50). I will test your suggestions. Thanks again!

node.title: Issue with compiling on WSL with old libmesh version
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I'm trying to install MOOSE on a Windows laptop. I've followed the "Getting Started" guide on WSL and Conda MOOSE environment installation. To compile my code I have to use an old version of libmesh (2021.01.14 is the last one that works without any conflict to resolve). So I tried to roll back to that version but I have the following warning when doing so:
Verifying transaction: -
SafetyError: The package for moose-libmesh located at /home/louis/miniconda3/pkgs/moose-libmesh-2021.01.14-build_1
appears to be corrupted. The path 'libmesh/include/libmesh/fparser.hh'
has an incorrect size.
reported size: 8484 bytes
actual size: 8192 bytes
SafetyError: The package for moose-libmesh located at /home/louis/miniconda3/pkgs/moose-libmesh-2021.01.14-build_1
appears to be corrupted. The path 'libmesh/include/libmesh/fparser_ad.hh'
has an incorrect size.
reported size: 7394 bytes
actual size: 4096 bytes
When I try to compile after that I get all sorts of errors with FunctionParser. Do you have any idea of what's wrong? I must add that I already tried to uninstall and reinstall the conda moose environment but I still run into the same issue. Another thing that might be related: the first time I tried to downgrade libmesh to 2021.01.14, I did not see the aforementioned error message and everything went fine during compiling (no error message about FunctionParser) until my computer crashed in the middle of the process...
Thank you,
Louis

I think every issue you are experiencing is due to our recent moose-libmesh dependency problem.
The details are available here, as well as the solution: #18378 to that specific issue.
I would ask that you simply "Try Again" by following the advice given in the aforementioned link. Basically, the steps will be:
conda deactivate
conda clean --all       # <-- adding this specifically in your case
conda env remove -n moose
conda create -n moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
conda activate moose
I added an additional step, as you do seem to possibly have a corrupted tarball package. I am not sure how that happened. But they fix is simple.
Also note: If conda install takes forever to solve (or begin), I would suggest using mamba. The details of which are also in the link above.
Thank you Jason I will try that :)

So I tried the steps you suggested, including the conda clean --all step, however, I still have the same corrupted package issue when downloading the 2021.01.14 version of moose-libmesh, leading to the same Function Parser related errors when compiling. Do you have any idea of what the issue might be?

I do not know what is causing the package to become corrupt... We have many machines which are downloading the very same package without error.
I don't think the package itself is corrupt, but lets test that. Can you curl the file manually, and perform an shasum on it?
curl -L -O https://anaconda.org/idaholab/moose-libmesh/2021.07.14/download/linux-64/moose-libmesh-2021.07.14-build_0.tar.bz2

# Your SHA should match mine:
sha256sum moose-libmesh-2021.07.14-build_0.tar.bz2 
4da68980e558030de93d658f2ac7ac5ead3f1c2892199f8f172898daa381a1f1  moose-libmesh-2021.07.14-build_0.tar.bz2
If the above failed, we are standing up a new server to host our moose packages, if you would like to give that a try:
conda deactivate
conda config --remove channels idaholab
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda config --env --set ssl_verify false          # <-- we don't have a proper SSL cert in place just yet
conda create -n new-moose moose-libmesh
Just installing moose-libmesh, to quickly test a corrupt package...
Is your MOOSE repo up-to-date?
cd moose
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/master
Other than the above I don't understand how the file is becoming corrupt. When you're finished troubleshooting, you may want to re-enable SSL:
conda config --remove channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
conda config --add channels idaholab
conda config --env --set ssl_verify true

@milljm I think he is trying to download an older version of libMesh from January.
@louisBS can you tell us your moose commit hash?

@hugary1995 you're right, I didn't see that. I suppose then, why is Conda doing that? The latest available packages have no dependency failures. The steps I outlined in my first response should have worked.
This statement sorta threw me for a loop:
To compile my code I have to use an old version of libmesh (2021.01.14 is the last one that works without any conflict to resolve)
I thought the conflict reference was to an actual conflict being caused by Conda packages. Which did happen recently.
So, @louisBS you are purposefully installing an older moose-libmesh and getting a corrupted download? I tried the below, but received no errors after installation. Admittedly I am using mamba, not conda, as I no longer have a stomach for the slow solve times (conda install mamba).
$> mamba create -n testing moose-libmesh=2021.01.14 moose-tools
<trimmed>
Finished moose-libmesh                        (00m:17s)              52 MB      3 MB/s
Downloading  [================================================] (00m:50s)   23.22 MB/s
Extracting   [================================================] (00m:50s)      58 / 58
Preparing transaction: done
Verifying transaction: done
Executing transaction: done
#
# To activate this environment, use
#
#     $ conda activate testing
#
# To deactivate an active environment, use
#
#     $ conda deactivate

@milljm @hugary1995 Yes, sorry for being unclear, I am indeed purposefully installing an older moose-libmesh. I just solved my problem by installing the same 2021.01.14 version of moose-libmesh but with mamba instead of conda as you suggested. It doesn't make much sense to me but I'm happy it works. Now my code compiles and runs just fine! Thank you for your time and answers guys.
If that can be of any interest for future troubleshooting, as I mentioned in my first message, the first time I tried to install libmesh 2021.01.14 a few days ago with conda it went fine (no message about corrupted packages) but my computer crashed while compiling. It's only after restarting my computer and trying to compile again that I got errors when compiling, as well as the message about corrupted package when trying to re-install the 2021.01.14 libmesh. As I just said, using mamba install instead of conda install solved the corrupted package issue.
mamba is just full of surprises 🎉
